item.title: OpenShift Jenkins configuration via JCasC plugin
item.description: Deploying Jenkins on Kubernetes provides significant benefits over a standard VM-based deployment. For example, we are gaining the ability to have project-specific Jenkins slaves (agents) on demand instead of having a pool of VMs idle waiting for a job. In vanilla Kubernetes, we can deploy Jenkins using Helm, and In OpenShift, we can deploy Jenkins via the developer’s catalog. As everyone has experienced, setting up Jenkins is a complex process. Both Jenkins and its plugins require some tuning and Configuration, with dozens of parameters to set within the web UI manage section.
